trans-unit.source: Add Offline Data Sync to your Android Mobile Services app | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add Offline Data Sync to your Android Mobile Services app | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services to cache and sync offline data in your Android application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services to cache and sync offline data in your Android application

trans-unit.source: Mobile apps can lose network connectivity when moving to an area without service, or due to network issues.
trans-unit.target: Mobile apps can lose network connectivity when moving to an area without service, or due to network issues.

trans-unit.source: For example, a construction industry app used at a remote construction site might need to enter scheduling data that is synced up to Azure later.
trans-unit.target: For example, a construction industry app used at a remote construction site might need to enter scheduling data that is synced up to Azure later.

trans-unit.source: With Azure Mobile Services offline sync, you can keep working when network connectivity is lost, which is essential to many mobile apps.
trans-unit.target: With Azure Mobile Services offline sync, you can keep working when network connectivity is lost, which is essential to many mobile apps.

trans-unit.source: With offline sync, you work with a local copy of your Azure SQL Server table, and periodically re-sync the two.
trans-unit.target: With offline sync, you work with a local copy of your Azure SQL Server table, and periodically re-sync the two.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll update the app from the [Mobile Services Quick Start tutorial] to enable offline sync, and then test the app by adding data offline, syncing those items to the online database, and verifying the changes in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll update the app from the [Mobile Services Quick Start tutorial] to enable offline sync, and then test the app by adding data offline, syncing those items to the online database, and verifying the changes in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Whether you are offline or connected, conflicts can arise any time multiple changes are made to data.
trans-unit.target: Whether you are offline or connected, conflicts can arise any time multiple changes are made to data.

trans-unit.source: A future tutorial will explore handling sync conflicts, where you choose which version of the changes to accept.
trans-unit.target: A future tutorial will explore handling sync conflicts, where you choose which version of the changes to accept.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we assume no sync conflicts and any changes you make to existing data will be applied directly to the Azure SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we assume no sync conflicts and any changes you make to existing data will be applied directly to the Azure SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: With offline sync you read to and write from a sync table (using the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface), which is part of a SQL Light database on your device.
trans-unit.target: With offline sync you read to and write from a sync table (using the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface), which is part of a SQL Light database on your device.

trans-unit.source: To push and pull changes between the device and Azure Mobile Services, you use a synchronization context (MobileServiceClient.SyncContext), which you initialize with the local database that you use to store data locally.
trans-unit.target: To push and pull changes between the device and Azure Mobile Services, you use a synchronization context (MobileServiceClient.SyncContext), which you initialize with the local database that you use to store data locally.

trans-unit.source: Add permission to check for network connectivity by adding this code to the AndroidManifest.xml file:
trans-unit.target: Add permission to check for network connectivity by adding this code to the AndroidManifest.xml file:

trans-unit.target: Add the following import statements to ToDoActivity.java:

trans-unit.source: Near the top of the ToDoActivity class, change the declaration of the mToDoTable variable from a MobileServiceTable class to a MobileServiceSyncTable class.
trans-unit.target: Near the top of the ToDoActivity class, change the declaration of the mToDoTable variable from a MobileServiceTable class to a MobileServiceSyncTable class.

trans-unit.source: This is where you define the sync table.
trans-unit.target: This is where you define the sync table.

trans-unit.target: To handle initialization of the local store, in the onCreate method, add the following lines after creating the MobileServiceClient instance:

trans-unit.target: Add this method to verify network connectivity:

trans-unit.target: Add this method to sync between the local SQL Light store and the Azure SQL Server:

trans-unit.target: In the onCreate method, add this code as the next-to-the-last line, right before the call to refreshItemsFromTable:

trans-unit.source: This causes the device on startup to sync with the Azure table.
trans-unit.target: This causes the device on startup to sync with the Azure table.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise you would display the last offline contents of the local store.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise you would display the last offline contents of the local store.

trans-unit.source: Update the code in the refreshItemsFromTable method to use this query (first line of code inside the try block):
trans-unit.target: Update the code in the refreshItemsFromTable method to use this query (first line of code inside the try block):

trans-unit.source: In the onOptionsItemSelected method replace the contents of the if block with this code:
trans-unit.target: In the onOptionsItemSelected method replace the contents of the if block with this code:

trans-unit.source: This code runs when you press the Refresh button in the upper right corner.
trans-unit.target: This code runs when you press the Refresh button in the upper right corner.

trans-unit.source: This is the main way you sync your local store to Azure, in addition to syncing at startup.
trans-unit.target: This is the main way you sync your local store to Azure, in addition to syncing at startup.

trans-unit.source: This encourages batching of sync changes, and is efficient given that the pull from Azure is a relatively expensive operation.
trans-unit.target: This encourages batching of sync changes, and is efficient given that the pull from Azure is a relatively expensive operation.

trans-unit.source: You could also design this app to sync on every change by adding a call to syncAsync to the addItem and checkItem methods, if your app required this.
trans-unit.target: You could also design this app to sync on every change by adding a call to syncAsync to the addItem and checkItem methods, if your app required this.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will test the behavior with WiFi on, and then turn off WiFi to create an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will test the behavior with WiFi on, and then turn off WiFi to create an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: When you add data items, they are held in the local SQL Light store, but not synced to the mobile service until you press the Refresh button.
trans-unit.target: When you add data items, they are held in the local SQL Light store, but not synced to the mobile service until you press the Refresh button.

trans-unit.source: Other apps may have different requirements regarding when data needs to be synchronized, but for demo purposes this tutorial has the user explicitly request it.
trans-unit.target: Other apps may have different requirements regarding when data needs to be synchronized, but for demo purposes this tutorial has the user explicitly request it.

trans-unit.source: When you press that button, a new background task starts, and first pushes all the changes made to the local store, by using the synchronization context, and then pulls all changed data from Azure to the local table.
trans-unit.target: When you press that button, a new background task starts, and first pushes all the changes made to the local store, by using the synchronization context, and then pulls all changed data from Azure to the local table.

trans-unit.source: Lets test the following scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Lets test the following scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Add some new items on your device;
trans-unit.target: Add some new items on your device;

trans-unit.source: Verify the items don't show in the portal;
trans-unit.target: Verify the items don't show in the portal;

trans-unit.source: next press Refresh and verify that they then show up.
trans-unit.target: next press Refresh and verify that they then show up.

trans-unit.source: Change or add an item in the portal, then press Refresh and verify that the changes show up on your device.
trans-unit.target: Change or add an item in the portal, then press Refresh and verify that the changes show up on your device.

trans-unit.source: Place the device or simulator in Airplane Mode.
trans-unit.target: Place the device or simulator in Airplane Mode.

trans-unit.source: This creates an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: This creates an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: Add some ToDo items, or mark some items as complete.
trans-unit.target: Add some ToDo items, or mark some items as complete.

trans-unit.source: Quit the device or simulator (or forcibly close the app) and restart.
trans-unit.target: Quit the device or simulator (or forcibly close the app) and restart.

trans-unit.source: Verify that your changes have been persisted on the device because they are held in the local SQL Light store.
trans-unit.target: Verify that your changes have been persisted on the device because they are held in the local SQL Light store.

trans-unit.source: View the contents of the Azure TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: View the contents of the Azure TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the new items have not been synced to the server:
trans-unit.target: Verify that the new items have not been synced to the server:

trans-unit.source: For the JavaScript backend, go to the Management Portal, and click the Data tab to view the contents of the TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: For the JavaScript backend, go to the Management Portal, and click the Data tab to view the contents of the TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: For the .NET backend, view the table contents either with a SQL tool such as SQL Server Management Studio, or a REST client such as Fiddler or Postman.
trans-unit.target: For the .NET backend, view the table contents either with a SQL tool such as SQL Server Management Studio, or a REST client such as Fiddler or Postman.

trans-unit.source: Turn on WiFi in the device or simulator.
trans-unit.target: Turn on WiFi in the device or simulator.

trans-unit.source: Next, press the Refresh button.
trans-unit.target: Next, press the Refresh button.

trans-unit.source: View the TodoItem data again in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: View the TodoItem data again in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: The new and changed TodoItems should now appear.
trans-unit.target: The new and changed TodoItems should now appear.
